summary: Background Hemophagocytic syndrome (HPS) is clinically defined as a combination of fever, liver dysfunction, coagulation abnormalities, pancytopenia, progressive macrophage proliferation throughout the reticuloendothelial system. it may be primary or secondary to infectious, auto-immune, and tumoral diseases. the pathognomonic characteristic of HPS is the activation of well-differentiated macrophages, phagocyting erythrocytes, leukocytes and platelets in bone marrow, lymph nodes, spleen, liver and other organs. the syndrome was first described in 1939 as poorly-controlled histiocyte proliferation, but has since also been called hemophagocytic histiocytosis and macrophage activation syndrome. the aim of this review is to make a critical appraisal of the literature concerning infection-related HPS in paediatrics. the study is to make a critical appraisal of the literature concerning infection-related HPS in paediatrics. the constellation of signs and symptoms of HPS is not specific and none of the biochemical abnormalities is distinctive. the dramatic presentation of the syndrome includes unremitting fever, visceromegaly, thrombocytopenia, lethargy, seizures, skin rash, pulmonary failure, and cardiac and/or renal involvement. the most common laboratory findings are due to liver dysfunction. e) hemophagocytosis in any involved organ f) with HPS other than EBV are cytomegalovirus (CMV) and human herpes virus 8 (HHV8).
